page_analysis.text_content:
Step 4: Finalize the determination of which segments are closed and which are open, total the linear feet in each category, and compare the totals.

For the porch in Fig 5, the summary is as follows:

Closed                    Open
Segment  Feet            Segment  Feet
A        3'              D        7'
B        8'              F        24'
C        10'             G        4'
E        14'
         35'                     35'

Conclusion: The perimeter of the porch in Fig 5 is 50% open and so the porch would NOT count toward gross floor area

Note: If a porch floor is more than 30" above grade, the porch sides may need to be 36" high for safety reasons. This may cause the porch facade to be considered closed. Possible solutions to make sure the porch sides are considered open are illustrated to the right:

• Railings (ballisters) instead of solid half walls.
• A single safety rail above lower, solid half walls.

10

visual_elements.description: Floor plan diagram showing a porch with labeled segments A through G, with dimensions marked. Shows closed segments (dark shaded) and open segments (light shaded). Dimensions include: D=7', B=8', C=10', F=24', G=4', A=3', E=14'. Total width appears to be 24' and height 14'.

Two side-view elevation drawings showing porch safety solutions. Left shows 'Open' with railings/ballisters, right shows 'Open' with safety rail above solid half wall. Shows measurements of 36' for porch floor height and 30' above grade, with safety rail indicated.
Summary table showing closed vs open segments with their linear feet measurements, totaling 35' each for closed and open segments

additional_notes: Page number 10 appears at bottom left

Legend shows closed segments as dark squares and open segments as light squares
